messageBody:
Hi Mike,

El Sábado, 21 de Junio de 2003 00:27, Mike Bresnahan escribió:
> [..]
> In these cases, it seems more sensical to me to
> write integration tests which involve both my code and the 3rd party API.
> How do people more familiar with unit testing handle such situations?

I've had this same dilemma for several months and the most satisfactory answer
I had found until now was doing Integration tests. That way I tested my code
at the same time I was learning how to use the 3rd party API. I've been
working this way more or less satisfactorily.

But somethig feels wrong with it, when I test this way I have less confidence
than with my other classes which are really unit tested. Also, when a test
fails it's significantly harder to find the error because I don't know if it
is in the code or in my understanding of the API.

Recently, I read about Learning Tests and have started using them for the
above situation. Now I'm starting to do this:
1) Make Learning Tests of the 3rd party API I'm about to use until I
understand completely the part I'm about to use.
2) Make unit tests of my code which uses the 3rd party API in a regular TDD
style. This tests can now do more intensive checking such as that the correct
calls to the 3rd party API are being done.

Unfortunately, I've not found a way to do this everytime, because the 3rd
party API must have MockObjects or they must be easy to construct, which is
not always true.

Some other side effects of using Learning Tests before using 3rd party APIs
are:
- They serve as documentation for other developers of the team. When many of
the team developers use this technique, you end up with a very useful
autotested library of examples of the 3rd party API.
- They help to spot the differences in behaviour when there is a new version
of the 3rd party API.

Cheers,
Jorge
